items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message:
River and lake levels remain high on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water following recent heavy rain. Flooding is mainly affecting areas of low lying land and footpaths near Derwent Water.

We are continuing to monitor river and lake levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths near watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 1/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Churn, Hilcot Brook, Daglingworth Stream, Gumstool Brook

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  

The forecast is mainly dry for the next few days.

Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Upper River Ouse

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message: River levels on the River Ouse are peaking following recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including King's Staith, Queen's Staith and South Esplanade. River levels are expected to start falling later this evening and into tomorrow, Thursday 01/02/2024. Some light rain is forecast for today, Wednesday 31/01/2024. Avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not walk or drive through floodwater. Please consider putting your flood plan into action. We are continuing to monitor the situation. This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels are rising on the River Derwent due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the upper River Derwent with low-lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Low Marishes. Light rain is forecast for today, Wednesday 31/01/2024. We are closely monitoring the situation. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This alert has been removed due to improving conditions. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Naburn Lock to Selby
items.message: River levels on the River Ouse are peaking following recent heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river in the Cawood, Kelfield, Wistow and Selby areas. River levels are expected to start falling later this evening and into tomorrow, Thursday 01/02/2024. Some light rain is forecast for today, Wednesday 31/01/2024. We continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Hull catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Holderness Drain, Barmston Drain

items.message: This alert remains in place as levels remain high on Beverley and Barmston Drain, Frodingham Beck and the River Hull due to recent prolonged rainfall and elevated groundwater levels. Levels on Roam Drain have stopped rising but remain very high. Areas most at risk are around the rivers and drains between Frodingham Bridge and the Wilfholme area, including low-lying land around Hempholme. Our pumping stations are operating to reduce levels, however water levels will remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected.

River levels are now falling on the River Pang following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. No further flooding of low lying land and roads is expected. 

The forecast is for today and tomorrow to be mainly dry. We expect river levels to continue to fall slowly, however river levels will remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 01/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Derwent

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire, York

items.message: River levels have risen on the River Derwent due to heavy rainfall. Areas most at risk include local roads and low-lying land around Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington. Light rain is forecast today, Wednesday 31/01/2024. We continue to monitor the situation closely. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Avon and tributaries

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message: River levels remain high due to groundwater but are slowly falling on the Lower Hampshire Avon and tributaries. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle and Lower Hampshire Avon, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch. The forecast is for a period of dry weather over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and river levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Ouse at York - riverside properties
items.message: River levels on the River Ouse are peaking following recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low-lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around properties on King's Staith in York and riverside areas through York, from Lendal Bridge to Millennium Bridge. River levels are expected to start falling later this evening and into tomorrow, Thursday 01/02/2024. Some light rain is forecast for today, Wednesday 31/01/2024. We are closing flood gates through the city and the Foss barrier is in operation. Act on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Og Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high, but currently stable at our observation borehole in Draycot Foliat in the Upper Og Valley, following winter rainfall across the area.

Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels.

Levels are currently stable but levels at this site are sensitive to individual rainfall events and will likely rise again following rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 02/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The forecast is for minimal rain over the next few days.
Water is still present on areas of the Somerset Levels and Moors but the Huish Episcopi Main Drain level is falling. We are monitoring water levels and continuing to pump out water from the Levels.

items.description: River Rye catchment
items.message: This alert has been removed due to improving conditions. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: Groundwater levels in Hambledon are high but slowly falling. In the last 7 days, the level at Whitedale Farm has fallen by 1.8m. Currently, we expect that a small number of properties on East and West Street will have water in the cellars. We expect that groundwater is currently impacting the sewerage system, and that water is affecting Fareham Road. Unsettled weather is expected on Thursday 25/01/2024 and Friday 26/01/2024, although rainfall totals in Hampshire are expected to be relatively small. Dry weather is forecast on Saturday 27/01/2024 and Sunday 28/01/2024. Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling during this time, and flooding impacts will slowly improve. We are liaising with Hambledon Flood Action Group and are monitoring the forecast. Please remain prepared for further flooding impacts this winter, and ensure that pumps used to reduce water levels can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 31/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: In Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle, groundwater levels remain high but have recently started slowly falling. In the Chalton Lavant, flows continue to reduce. Flow in the Idsworth Lavant continues to be high. We expect a small number of properties to be experiencing cellar flooding. Minor impact road flooding, and impacts to the sewerage network are ongoing. Over the next 5 days, only very small amounts of rainfall are forecast. Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling during this time, and flooding impacts will slowly improve. We are monitoring the forecast. Please remain prepared for further impacts this winter, surface water may flood property during heavier rain events. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday 01/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high in response to winter rainfall across the area. Levels are high but are currently falling slowly at our observation borehole in Longacre in the Lambourn Valley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater.

The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels, and levels will likely rise again following rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message by 02/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Hull Central catchment

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, Kingston upon Hull
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Hull, Beverley and Barmston Drain

items.message: This alert remains in place as levels remain high on Beverley and Barmston Drain and the River Hull. Areas most at risk include the River Hull area around Arram, Tickton, Beverley and Dunswell. Our pumping stations are operating to reduce levels, however water levels will remain high. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Tees and estuarine tributaries

floodArea.county: County Durham, Darlington, Hartlepool, Middlesbrough, North Yorkshire, Stockton-on-Tees

items.message:
River levels are falling this evening. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.
 
No further rainfall is forecast overnight.
 
We will continue to monitor levels closely.
 
There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.
 
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.

Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: River Foulness and Market Weighton catchment

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Foulness, Market Weighton Canal, North Cave Beck, Ellerker Beck, Mill Beck

items.message: This alert remains in place as river levels remain high on the River Foulness and Market Weighton Catchment. Flooding is expected to affect locations near Mill Beck in Market Weighton, on Market Weighton Canal, Ings Beck in North Newbald, North Cave Beck in North Cave and the River Foulness near Welham Bridge, with low-lying land expected to be most affected. We continue to monitor river levels closely. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Low lying properties in the Upper Hull catchment
items.message: This warning remains in place as river levels in the upper River Hull catchment remain high following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Areas most at risk include the River Hull and its tributaries at Frodingham, Hempholme, Wilfholme and Burshill, including Roam Drain. We are operating pumps in the area and continue to monitor the situation. Put your flood plan into action and avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Groundwater is high, within 50 cm of the surface in the Lavant valley, but slowly falling. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. Small amounts of water could still affect some roads. Other than a light, brief and isolated shower, no rain is forecast this week (through to Friday 02/02/2024). High pressure could keep most rain away from the south throughout February, with a cooler period possible for mid February. Groundwater in all boreholes will continue falling this week. However, groundwater will remain close to the surface in communities, and minor flood impacts could continue through to March. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any additional rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 03/02/2024

items.description: Upper River Aire catchment
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. Levels remain elevated but are falling and will continue to fall this evening and into tomorrow. Standing water may remain on low lying land near the river, particularly in the Kildwick area, so please continue to take care.
Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow afternoon, 31/01/2024. We are not expecting rainfall totals to be as high as on Monday, however, we may see the river respond again tomorrow evening. We will continue to monitor the forecast and river levels closely and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Lower River Ure

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ure, Swinney Beck, Bishop Monkton Beck, River Skell, River Laver, River Tutt, Stainley Beck

items.message: River levels are falling but remain high on the River Skell and River Ure, due to recent heavy rainfall. Flooding is possible near the River Skell with low-lying land expected to be most affected, including agricultural land and local roads in the areas around Masham, Boroughbridge, Aldborough and Bishop Monkton. Light rain is forecast today, Wednesday 31/01/2024. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 9:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Wiske and other tributaries of the River Swale, with low-lying land expected to be most affected. Light rain is forecast for today, Wednesday 31/01/2024. We will continue to monitor the situation closely. We will continue to monitor groundwater levels in the area.

items.message: River levels on the River Ouse are peaking following recent heavy rainfall. River levels are expected to start falling later this evening and into tomorrow, Thursday 01/02/2024. Some light rain is forecast for today, Wednesday 31/01/2024. We are closing flood gates through the city and the Foss barrier is in operation. Act on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low-lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Naburn Lock Buildings and Lock Cottages. River levels are expected to start falling later this evening and into tomorrow, Thursday 01/02/2024. Some light rain is forecast for today, Wednesday 31/01/2024. We are closing flood gates through the city and the Foss barrier is in operation. Act on your flood plan if you have one. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and do not attempt to walk, cycle or drive through flood water. items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected.

River levels are high on the Ginge Brook following recent rainfall. Water is expected to remain in, and on low lying land and roads over the next few days. 

The forecast is for today and tomorrow to be mainly dry. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. 

We are monitoring the situation. Please report any blockages to the Environment Agency on 0800 80 70 60. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 01/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Osbaldwick Beck and Tanghall Beck
items.message: This alert has been removed due to improving conditions. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Middle River Aire catchment
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. They will continue to fall for the remainder of the day and into tomorrow. Standing water may remain on low lying land near the river so please continue to take care.
Further rainfall is forecast tomorrow afternoon, 31/01/2024. We are not expecting rainfall totals to be as high as on Monday, however, we may see the river respond again tomorrow evening. We will continue to monitor the forecast and river levels closely and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Groundwater is high, close to the surface, but slowly falling at the Compton borehole. Minor groundwater flood impacts will likely continue, with springs affecting fields and small amounts of water on roads including Stoughton main road and the road from East Marden. Groundwater could affect a small number of properties close to the village green Stoughton and possibly basements or near the ground floor of properties in Walderton too. Other than a light, brief and isolated shower, no rain is forecast through to Friday 02/02/2024. High pressure could keep most rain away from the south throughout February, with a cooler period possible for mid February. Groundwater will continue falling this week, although will remain close to the surface, and minor flood impacts could continue through to mid February. Groundwater will remain higher than normal and sensitive to any rainfall over winter. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 03/02/2024

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected.

River levels are now falling slowly along the Lower River Kennet following high levels. No further flooding of low lying land and roads is expected.

The forecast is for today and tomorrow to be mainly dry.  We expect river levels to continue to fall over the coming days, but levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 01/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This alert has been removed due to improving conditions. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Tidal River Ouse from Selby to Faxfleet

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message:
River levels are high on the Tidal River Ouse as a result of a combination of high tides and recent rainfall. 
Areas most at risk include the tidal foreshore and agricultural land adjacent to the river from the A63 near Selby to the Yokefleet, Blacktoft and Faxfleet areas. Further light rainfall is forecast this afternoon. We have closed locks and flood gates in the area. 
We continue to monitor levels closely. People in these areas should consider taking action now. We urge all people to take care and not drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:30pm on 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Eden
Groundwater flooding in the Cranborne Chase area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have now fallen back and with little rainfall in the forecast, there is now no risk of further flooding.
We will continue to monitor groundwater levels in the area.

items.description: River Foss
items.message: This alert has been removed due to improving conditions. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: River Bourne and tributaries
items.message: River levels remain high on the River Bourne at Idmiston and Salisbury Bourne river gauges due to groundwater. We are monitoring river levels in the area. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have. Start acting on your flood plan if you have one. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels in villages surrounding Andover remain very high. Cellar flooding is expected to be ongoing in Appleshaw, Hatherden, Penton Grafton and Penton Mewsey. Ongoing flooding impacts are expected to be impacting Deacon and Down Road in Kimpton, the main road in Penton Grafton, and the road from Biddesden to Appleshaw. Sewerage system impacts are expected in most villages. Surface water flood risk continues in Thruxton. From today (30/01/2024) until Saturday (03/02/2024), dry weather is forecast. Groundwater levels are expected to fall and impacts will improve slowly this week. We continue to monitor the forecast. Groundwater levels will remain sensitive to further heavy rainfall this winter, please remain prepared. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 06/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: Groundwater levels in Hursley remain very high but have fallen by 24cm in the last week. Widespread cellar flooding and impacts to the sewerage system are expected to be ongoing. Residual flood water may be affecting the ground floor of isolated properties. From today (30/01/2024) until Saturday (03/02/2024), dry weather is forecast. Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling and impacts will improve slowly this week. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 06/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Meon Valley from East Meon to Soberton
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Meon Valley are high but continue to fall. At Pound Lane in Meonstoke, levels have fallen by 68cm in the last week. The Winterbourne in Meonstoke is still flowing from beyond Rectory Lane to the Bucks Head pub. While groundwater levels remain high there are likely to be impacts on low lying sewerage systems throughout the valley. Unsettled weather is expected on Thursday 25/01/2024 and Friday 26/01/2024, although rainfall totals in Hampshire are expected to be relatively small. Dry weather is forecast on Saturday 27/01/2024 and Sunday 28/01/2024. Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling throughout the next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If levels continue to fall for the next week and further dry weather is forecast, it is possible this Flood Alert could be removed next week. Please remain prepared for further flooding impacts this winter as groundwater and river levels will be sensitive to further rainfall. We will update or remove the Flood Alert by 18:00 on Wednesday 31/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Salisbury Plain area
items.message: Groundwater levels continue to fall across Salisbury Plain and the West Wiltshire Downs. With little rainfall forecast over the next few days, the risk of groundwater flooding has receded for the foreseeable future. Environment agency staff will continue to monitor the situation and will respond should the need require.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Twyford and Hensting
items.message: Groundwater levels in Twyford and Hensting remain high but are slowly falling. We expect a small number of properties in Twyford and Hensting to be affected by cellar flooding. There is water on the road in Hensting Lane. The spring at Finch’s Lane is issuing, and the Bourne is flowing in the ditch on Hazeley Road. Unsettled weather is expected on Thursday 25/01/2024 and Friday 26/01/2024, although rainfall totals in Hampshire are expected to be relatively small. Dry weather is forecast on Saturday 27/01/2024 and Sunday 28/01/2024. Groundwater levels in Twyford and Hensting are expected to continue falling during this time and flooding impacts will slowly improve. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 31/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Vernham Dean, Upton and the Bourne Valley
items.message: In the Bourne Valley, groundwater levels remain very high but are slowly falling. We expect cellar flooding at Upton, Hurstbourne Tarrant, Stoke, Vernham Dean and St Mary Bourne. Isolated properties may be experiencing ground floor flooding. The road through Upton is flooded. Groundwater is affecting the sewerage system in all villages. Over the next five days, only very small amounts of rainfall are forecast. Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling, and flooding impacts will slowly improve. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast and have deployed flood barriers at St Mary Bourne to help manage flood risk. Please ensure any pumps used to reduce water levels are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday 01/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bramdean and Cheriton
items.message: Groundwater levels in Bramdean and Cheriton are high but slowly falling. Since Wednesday 17/01/2024, the level at Cheriton Wood has fallen by 35cm. We expect that isolated properties in Cheriton are being affected by cellar flooding. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively in both villages. Unsettled weather is expected on Thursday 25/01/2024 and Friday 26/01/2024, although rainfall totals in Hampshire are expected to be relatively small. Dry weather is forecast on Saturday 27/01/2024 and Sunday 28/01/2024. Groundwater levels in Bramdean and Cheriton are expected to continue falling during this time and flooding impacts will slowly improve. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you use pumps to reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday 31/01/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in East Kent
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: Groundwater levels in East Kent have risen following recent higher than average rainfall and are expected to remain high until Spring 2024. The Alkham Bourne and the Nailbourne between Lyminge and Littlebourne are flowing. Flows in the Little Stour between Littlebourne and Stourmouth have increased over the past month. Localised flooding may affect low-lying land, roads, and water infrastructure in and around the Elham Valley, Alkham, and Petham. Other communities in East Kent may also be impacted. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. The forecast is for more settled conditions into next week, with the exception of some light showers in the early morning of Friday 26 January 2024. We are monitoring the situation and are working with local authorities and communities with the deployment of temporary defences, such as Canterbury City Council’s temporary defences in Barham. Our staff are maintaining and clearing key structures. This message will be updated by Thursday 1 February 2024, or as the situation changes. Search ‘Kent Groundwater Situation’ on gov.uk.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message: In Kings Somborne and Little Somborne, groundwater levels remain high but are falling slowly. At our borehole in Kings Somborne, levels have fallen by 21cm in the last week. Isolated properties in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne may still be pumping water out of their cellars. Tankering of sewerage is ongoing. From today (30/01/2024) until Saturday (03/02/2024), dry weather is forecast. Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling and impacts will improve slowly this week. We continue to monitor the forecast. Groundwater levels will remain sensitive to further heavy rainfall this winter, please remain prepared. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operational. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 06/02/2024.

items.description: Gypsey Race and the Wolds

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire

items.message: This alert remains in place as river levels remain high on the Gypsey Race due to recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Gypsey Race, with low-lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around the Gypsey Race from Wold Newton to Bridlington. Groundwater will remain high for some time. We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower Dunsforth Access
items.message: This alert has been removed due to improving conditions. We continue to monitor the forecast and will reissue this alert if necessary.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: In Preston Candover and Old Alresford, groundwater levels remain very high but have recently peaked and are now slowly falling. We expect a small number of properties in Preston Candover and Old Alresford will be pumping water out of their cellars. In Old Alresford, residual flood water may be affecting the ground floor of 1 property. Groundwater levels are reducing the ability of septic tanks to operate effectively. Over the next 5 days, only very small amounts of rainfall are forecast. Groundwater levels in the Candovers and Old Alresford are expected to continue falling during this time, and flooding impacts will slowly improve. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please ensure that pumps used to reduce water levels are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday 01/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bishops Sutton
items.message: Groundwater levels in Bishops Sutton are high and relatively stable. Groundwater levels are just below the threshold we would expect a small number of properties to experience cellar flooding. Minor impacts to septic tanks and flooding of roads, such as the B3047, is expected to be ongoing. From today (30/01/2024) until Saturday (03/02/2024), dry weather is forecast. Groundwater levels are expected to remain high but may just begin falling during this period. We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they can operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 06/02/2024.

items.description: Roam Drain and River Hull at Hempholme
items.message: This warning remains in place as levels remain very high on Roam Drain following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Areas most at risk include properties in Hempholme and around Hunt Hill Farm. River levels are steady but are expected to remain high and flooding of properties will continue. We are operating pumps in the area and continue to closely monitor the situation. Put your flood plan into action and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 5:00pm on Wednesday 31/01/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Kennet and its tributaries from Berwick Bassett down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. 

River levels are high on the River Kennet following recent rainfall. Water may remain on low lying land and roads over the next few days. 

The forecast is for today and tomorrow to be mainly dry. 

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 01/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Bourne Valley - The Winterbournes
items.message:
Groundwater levels have now fallen back and with little rainfall in the forecast, there is now no risk of further flooding.
We will continue to monitor groundwater levels in the area.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high at our observation borehole at Northfield Farm near Great Shefford, in response to the winter rainfall across the area. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may now be affected by flooding from groundwater. 

Groundwater levels are currently steady but could rise further if we see persistent or heavy rain. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 02/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Burn from Southgate and Waterden to Burnham Thorpe
items.message: This message has been issued because of the continued risk of flooding to homes and businesses today, Wednesday 31st January 2024. River levels remain higher than normal in response to rainfall earlier this month. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas in South Creake and Burnham Thorpe, including parts of the B1355. The forecast is for a period of dry weather, which will allow the rivers to start to return to normal levels. We expect the river level to continue to fall slowly. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation closely. We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Thursday 1st February.

items.description: River Lambourn from Upper Lambourn to Great Shefford
items.message:
Further property flooding is not expected.

River levels on the River Lambourn are high following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Further flooding of property is not expected, but flooding of roads and low lying land may continue today, 31/01/2024, especially in the Eastbury area. 

The forecast is for today and tomorrow to be mainly dry. Levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Please avoid contact with flood water and be aware of flooded roads, do not drive through floodwater. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 01/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected.

A flood warning remains in force for the Upper River Lambourn at Eastbury. 

River levels are high as a result of high groundwater levels and rainfall over the last month.  Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, 31/01/2024. 

The forecast is for today and tomorrow to be mainly dry. We expect river levels to slowly fall, however they will remain sensitive to further rainfall.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be aware of floodwater remaining on the flood plain as river levels recede. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated tomorrow, 01/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Nailbourne and Little Stour
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Little Stour, Nailbourne, River Wingham, River Stour

items.message: River levels remain high on the Little Stour and Nailbourne. The risk of flooding of roads and low-lying land is expected to remain throughout the weekend and into next week. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads along the River Nailbourne around Bekesbourne, and areas along the Little Stour around Littlebourne. Flooding of property is not currently expected. Please avoid driving or walking through floodwater. The forecast is for more settled and dry conditions this week. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required. This message will be updated by 6pm on Wednesday 31 January 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are high but are beginning to stabilise after the recent dry weather. In the last week, groundwater levels at Oakley have risen by just 6cm. Groundwater springflows are impacting land and roads, as well as the ability of septic tanks to operate properly. We expect that properties in Deane will be affected by cellar flooding. From today (30/01/2024) until Saturday (03/02/2024), dry weather is forecast. Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe are expected to remain high during this period but will begin to slowly fall. If further heavy rain affects the area in the coming weeks, it is possible the access road from the B3400 into Deane (at Deane Park) may need to be closed. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you use pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 06/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Pitton, West Tytherley, Nether Wallop and Broughton
items.message: Groundwater levels at Lopcombe Corner are high but have fallen by 2m in the last week. At Nether Wallop, some cellars may still be affected by groundwater. In Over Wallop, land and gardens may be experiencing minor ponding of water. In Pitton, impacts to the sewerage network are expected to be ongoing, and residual flood water may still be affecting cellars and road. At West Tytherley, groundwater levels are relatively stable very close to the level we expect cellar, land and road flooding. Today (29/01/2024), up to 9mm of rain is expected in Hampshire. From Tuesday 30/01/2024 to Friday 02/02/2024, dry weather is forecast. We expect groundwater levels in all villages to fall over the next week and flooding impacts will slowly improve. If dry weather continues to be forecast, we may remove this Flood Alert next week. We continue to monitor the forecast. Groundwater levels will be sensitive to further heavy rainfall this winter, please remain prepared. Please ensure that pumps used to reduce water levels are operational. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Monday 05/02/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Littleton, Headbourne, Kings and Martyr Worthy, Easton and Chilland
items.message: At Harestock, groundwater levels are high but continue to fall by around 17cm per day. The weather over the next 5 days is forecast to be relatively dry. Any residual minor flood impacts are expected to reduce during this time. If heavy rainfall affects the area in February or March, groundwater levels may rise again, and flooding impacts could return. Should this occur, then we will issue further advice. We advise all residents to remain prepared over the coming weeks.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message:
Groundwater levels are high and are slowly rising due to winter rainfall across the area at our Hodcott observation borehole near West Ilsley. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may now be affected by flooding from groundwater. 

The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 02/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Newmarket
items.message: Groundwater levels are falling in this area but will remain responsive to any further rainfall. This message applies to areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street.   Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate.  We will update this message in 7 days time, by 11:00am Wednesday 7th February.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Alton area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have risen in response to recent rainfall across the area and have risen above the level that requires early awareness at the Farringdon observation borehole. Groundwater levels are higher than normal for this time of year, and have currently stabilised at this high level. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and levels may start to increase again as we receive further rainfall. Low-lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.
We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 06/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Upper Aldbourne Valley
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the winter rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole at Water Acre in the Aldbourne Valley. The level is currently falling slowly. 

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may be affected by flooding from groundwater. We expect levels to remain high over the next few weeks, and levels remains sensitive to rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 02/02/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Leckhampstead area
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to the recent rainfall across the area and have risen at our observation borehole in the Leckhampstead area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected within the next few weeks, by flooding from groundwater.

Groundwater levels in this area are rising slowly, and we expect to see them continuing to rise if we receive further rainfall over the next few weeks. Low-lying land and roads will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 02/02/2024, or as the situation changes.
